Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy, but it might not be. In many developed countries, rubbish collection is a common service. Rubbish bags or bins are collected by special trucks and taken to a landfill. Economists find this service strange because it is usually free. Households pay for it through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that throws away very little. However, the cost of disposing of rubbish is not zero. More rubbish means more collectors and trucks are needed, and local authorities have to pay more for landfill fees. This is a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. The obvious solution is to make households pay for the amount of rubbish they throw away. This would encourage them to throw out less and recycle more, assuming there are places to recycle. 
However, two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this approach can have complicated and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns and cities that started charging households for rubbish. The most common system is to sell stickers or tags that people attach to rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these labels are collected. In a study of Charlottesville, Virginia, where residents were charged 80 cents per bag, the number of bags fell by 37%. But this was mainly because people packed more rubbish into each bag, a method called the 'Seattle stomp'. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14%. In other Virginian cities without this pricing, it fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also resorted to illegal dumping to avoid paying. 
One positive outcome was a 15% increase in recycling, as people chose to recycle for free rather than pay for rubbish collection. However, this might not be due to the fee, as many were already recycling voluntarily. In a broader study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that pricing does reduce rubbish weight, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices only reduces rubbish by 0.3%. This is because to significantly reduce rubbish, people would need to buy less of almost everything, and a small fee is unlikely to change that. Other factors like income and education might be just as important. In richer towns, people throw out more rubbish and have less time to recycle. 
So, should we stop charging for rubbish? Not necessarily. Free disposal is too cheap, but simple policies can have complex effects. Detailed economic models are needed to understand them, and sometimes the results are not as expected.

Theodore Zeldin explores how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many professions feel undervalued, and even famous people can feel bitter. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This is important because if your skills make you boring or unable to talk to people outside your field, or if you're too busy to gain wisdom or use your imagination, then no amount of status or money will make up for being unfulfilled as a person.
Zeldin wants to find out how work can help us achieve personal fulfillment, rather than just shaping us to fit industrial needs. Work should not only create wealth but also be a meaningful way of life, helping us discover new talents and meet different people. However, this doesn't mean getting rid of unemployment is the only goal. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and useful. A career should be like a work of art, with a fulfilled person at its center.
Even middle-class jobs are not as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients, accountants worry about ethics, architects rarely use their creativity, and administrators are stuck in bureaucracy. Middle managers are losing confidence in their roles. Companies and public institutions are getting smaller, and ideas like decentralizing decisions and rewarding performance haven't made employees more committed. In Britain, only 8% of employees strongly feel their values match their organization's values.
Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they shape or harm people. He looks at how different cultures have expanded what humans can do and how courage can be developed. He applies this to important topics like happiness, love, friendship, and respect. Now, he is focusing on finding more satisfying ways to work. Many experts work on extending the life and income of companies, but we also need to evaluate ourselves as people and decide who we want to spend our lives with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many are like part-time slaves, stuck in jobs because we see no other choice?
Take hotel workers, for example. They make up 10% of the workforce in the hospitality industry. Many smart and lively people work in hotels with low prestige, low pay, and long hours because hotels haven't changed much since the days of the Ritz. A hotel is more than a place to sleep; it's like a mini United Nations where people from all over the world meet but often don't interact. Many hotel staff are foreigners eager to learn new languages and cultures, but they have shallow interactions with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, connecting guests with the city and each other. They could use the skills of the students they hire, instead of just giving them basic tasks. If hotels focused on their staff's ambitions, they could offer more services. But accountants often say businesses should focus on one main activity to maximize profits. It's time to rethink this from a human perspective, not just a financial one.
For Zeldin, work is about relationships. As people want more independence and don't just want to follow orders, they should have the chance to design their own jobs and choose their colleagues and customers, within practical and profitable limits. This means they need to communicate beyond professional jargon and connect with people who might seem different at first. Everyone knows communication is important, but it's different from conversation. The new kind of conversation people miss today is more personal and creates respect between people. It's a way to understand others deeply and be changed by the experience. It's more than just relaxing; it's a way to create equality. Every meaningful conversation changes the world a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**
The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds widely by hand. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents the optimistic growth of modern society. It suggests spreading information widely, like seeds, to produce a rich outcome if conditions are right. This metaphor assumes there is a central source of information, like a bucket of seeds, ready to be shared and reproduced.
The question is why a new technology that could send words and pictures electronically was organized in a way that fit this farming metaphor. Television, like the telegraph and telephone, is a form of communication. However, from the start, it was seen as a central 'mass' medium. Sending broadcasts from a central place to private homes matched the social and economic structures of modern societies. Other ways of organizing television were tried but remained just experiments.
Two lesser-known alternatives show what television could have been in a different social setting. In the early 1930s, radio enthusiasts in Britain experimented with two-way television as a possible replacement for the telephone. Magazines like Radio News published articles on building TV transmitters and receivers, and many amateurs were active. However, in 1938, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards that pushed these grassroots efforts aside. This ended the chance for television to develop as a widespread, equal form of communication in Britain.
Broadcasting was linked to strong economic interests and the deep structures of modern societies. Despite the efforts of TV amateurs, television in the USA in the early 1930s was mainly a medium for public viewing, often seen as a competitor to the film industry. In Britain and Germany, public viewing was how most people first experienced television. While grassroots, two-way television was unlikely to succeed, public viewing systems in several countries in the 1930s could have challenged the idea of TV as a home-based medium. But this challenge did not happen.
Manufacturers saw the potential for mass sales of home TV sets once prices dropped. With the division between public and private life in modern society, central broadcasting to homes was the most suitable way to organize TV. As working-class people improved their living standards and joined consumer society from the 1920s, the dream of the home as a center for entertainment became possible for many in Western countries. This trend is now happening globally.
There is a link between social modernization and the main structures of broadcasting. As societies modernized, power and capital became more centralized, and traditional communities broke up, creating new ways of life. People became more mobile, both socially and geographically, leading to more isolated lives compared to stable early communities. Centralized broadcasting helped governments reach all citizens with important information and created a sense of national community.
Broadcasting became the dominant form of radio and television because of these structured processes and interests. However, broadcasting also played a positive role in democracy. Between the World Wars, many countries saw broadcasting as a way to ensure equal access to information needed for informed participation in political, social, and cultural life.
Television is changing, and the term 'broadcasting' might become outdated. If that happens, this metaphor will be seen as describing a specific way of organizing audio-visual technology during a certain phase of social modernization.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes, it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes the desire to get more things goes too far. Modern advertising is made to make us feel insecure. It often tells us that if we don't have a certain product, we are not good enough. To see how much ads affect you, try not to read any billboards next time you walk down the street. These expensive ads influence us in strong ways without us noticing. We see them everywhere—on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, T-shirts, the internet—all telling us to buy more.
**Caves**  
Research centers and universities around the world have spent years studying caves, focusing on their origins, water systems, and biology. Caves are a small but mysterious part of nature, which makes us curious and eager to learn more. This is why a lot of research has been done on them. In some parts of the world, caves have even affected how people live. However, exploring caves often requires physical skill, so cave research is not just done by professors. There is a unique mix of professional scientists and amateur explorers who study caves, often for fun.
**Weather Watch**  
Many people, using only their senses, laid the groundwork for meteorology, which has become a very technical science since the 17th century. Today, satellites and electronic tools give us weather information quickly, and computers solve complex math problems faster than humans can. Meteorological theory uses long words that can be hard to understand for non-experts. It might seem like there's no room for simple weather knowledge, but that's not true. Human experience is still important for turning data into weather forecasts. Observations from people can provide unique insights that help professionals understand the atmosphere better.

**Music and Theatre**
Until recently, I believed opera was mainly about theatre. But after working at a national opera house, I realized that music is the most important part of opera. This makes sense, but I come from the theatre world, where the spoken word and the actor are most important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once the play starts, and the audience usually understands the language spoken by the actors.
In music performances, like concerts or operas, many people, including myself, may not have a deep understanding of music. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A talented singer or a perfect orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows the results of years of hard work. Watching a great music performance is like watching a sports event; we know athletes are doing something similar to what we do when running, but they do it much better.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often don't understand an actor's skill and aren't as impressed by something that seems like what they could do themselves. They don't usually applaud when an actor finishes a long speech, although they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are more generous or less demanding than music audiences. In fact, many people attend both. But in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how challenging the play is.
The question is, should music learn from theatre about this relationship? I think yes, because a different approach can change the concert experience. Live music is naturally theatrical, full of emotion and drama, and can reach the listener's imagination. However, the formal traditions in music, like strict dress codes and high respect for conductors and soloists, can make the experience feel hierarchical. On the other hand, when audiences applaud between movements or after a great performance, it can disrupt the flow of the music, even if it's meant as appreciation.
Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done to attract new audiences to concerts and operas and to make serious music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a high-quality musical experience that involved the audience directly, changing many people's lives.
I wish music had more of the risk and boldness that theatre can have. Sometimes this comes from performing in unusual places, which can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, with poor acoustics or cold temperatures, but theatre audiences have learned to follow artists into unexpected spaces. Most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts, but I believe music conventions can and should change.
I am just an enthusiast who loves theatre and music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**
While I admire how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, I don't really like it in its natural form. For me, sand is mostly an annoying obstacle between a car park by the sea and the water. It blows into your face, gets into your food, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you're wet, sand sticks to you like glue and is hard to remove, even with a strong water spray. But strangely, as soon as you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, it falls off you. For days, you keep finding sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more comes out when you remove your socks. Sand stays with you longer than some illnesses. Personally, I can do without sand.
**Lock and Key**
The need for a safe home, privacy, and security has been around since humans first built permanent homes. The simple wooden bar behind the door has been replaced by electronic locks that use a plastic card with countless combinations, but the desire to keep out intruders is still strong. The attraction of a lock and key is partly psychological. Recently, some companies have tried computerized locking systems, where smart cards control electronic locks. However, people don't like them much. You might accept them at work, but at home, everyone prefers the comfort of turning a real key in a lock. So, when one locksmith company created a new electronic system, they made sure to include a real metal key in the design.
**Modern Art**
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I find modern art confusing. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and large photographs. Maybe if I knew more about it, I would have opinions on more pieces. But you're not supposed to analyze it like a school essay. The idea is to let art speak to you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to help visitors understand the reasons behind the artworks. The first thing I noticed were the labels, which explained the context and meaning of the art. Instead of just staring at the pictures without understanding, these bits of information helped me get what the art was about.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**
When novels are turned into films, the story often needs to be shortened and simplified. This can be frustrating for the writer, but it can also be enlightening. While working on a script, I noticed that much of the dialogue and description in a novel can be left out, yet the main point still comes across. This doesn't mean the original text was unnecessary. It's about how each medium—books and films—engages the audience differently and uses repetition in its own way. In novels, repetition helps readers remember character traits and who is speaking. In plays, dialogue often mimics real speech, sometimes using a lot of unnecessary words just to keep the conversation going, which can make it hard to understand what's really being said.
**Watching Movies**
Watching movies can be an immersive experience, making you feel like you're part of the film's world. For the duration of the movie, you escape from reality. However, once the movie ends and the lights come on, you're back in the real world. In the past, movies were often seen as just entertainment, not art. Many people, including our parents and teachers, thought movies were not serious or artistic.
**The Film Studios**
The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of different buildings, making it hard to navigate. There were a few permanent landmarks, like the Script Department, but many rooms looked the same and were hard to find. The studio had three main entrances, all similar, and none had a place to ask for directions. This made it confusing for newcomers, but most people who worked there knew their way around. The studio's work brought romance and adventure to audiences, helping them escape from everyday life for a few hours.
**Film-makers**
Many people dream of making movies. Bookstores are full of guides on scriptwriting and film production, and universities offer courses on the subject. Competitions offer cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make his film El Mariachi, which cost $7,000 and made him a well-known director. Rodriguez achieved his dream early, making his breakthrough film by age 23. In the past, filmmakers took longer to succeed. They often started as editors, writers, or cinematographers, learning their craft before directing. John Huston was 35 when he made his first film, and Fred Zinnemann found success in his forties. Today, without the support of studios, aspiring filmmakers often have to be independent and resourceful.

In those days, the council houses covered the western side of the city. They were rows of crowded, dull homes made of orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In the summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, would fill the air with a strong sulfur smell. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked up to someone's front door. 
Most of my early life is a blur, but I do remember sitting, or maybe balancing, near an upstairs window, watching the houses fade into the distance. Later, I have memories of faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that might not have been ours, and snow falling over the turrets of a big mansion at Earlham. My mother often appears in these early memories. I remember her as a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't do anything to make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or on longer trips into the city, I sensed that she was a bit unusual. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, as alone in a room full of people as she would be on a moor. She also had a strict sense of propriety, which was rare on the West Earlham estate. This sometimes led to intense cleaning or handwashing and instructions to 'behave properly'. As a moral code, it was beyond my understanding, and even now, I'm not sure I get it. It meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes, sitting quietly for long periods in the dining room with hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and many other rules.
Despite her solitude, my mother had a few friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who was obsessed with the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was livelier and somewhat disapproved of by the others. Later, I realized that this group was not great company. They often talked about bad legs, cold weather, and ungrateful children, a category I often felt I was in. Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' was on my shoulders, and I needed to grow up to lift it off. This was not easy. Growing up in West Earlham followed a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home, often getting in your parents' way. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug while my mother sat coldly in an armchair. Then, after your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile away. Some lucky kids had a mother with a rickety bike and a child seat. I think my mother let other children in the street take me to school.
If I remember anything from those early years, it's the summer holidays. Those were the days when you got glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity fete at a house far away on Christchurch Road, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and tried to interest me in something called the League of Pity, a junior charity. But my mother dismissed it, saying the organizers just wanted money. My mother often talked about people having mercenary motives, and she had a deep contempt for politicians. If she thought about the House of Commons, she probably imagined it as a fancy post office where rich people opened letters full of money from a gullible public. I might be exaggerating, and I might be ignoring her good qualities and focusing on her flaws. But my mother didn't have much kindness; it seemed to have been taken from her. 
To be fair, my mother did care about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she would take me, dressed in my 'good clothes', on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. There, we would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother wasn't completely against this activity and eventually started to have opinions on the art. I remember her once stopping in front of a painting of a Roman soldier and saying, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' This was one of the few times I remember her trying to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**
I walked down the odd-numbered side of Philadelphia Avenue. The evening was getting darker, and the air was thick and humid, turning into a light drizzle. This made my walk feel secretive and sheltered. I knew this side of the street well since childhood. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends, all girls, lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. Each house was familiar to me, just like the small channels in the cement that carried rainwater from the roofs to the street. As I moved down the street, I noticed that the houses seemed to change slightly in social status; the porches were closer to the ground, and the front yards were smaller. Over the years, some things had changed: wooden porch railings and pillars were replaced with wrought iron in a style that seemed Southern or Spanish. In Shillington, some houses I remembered as homes had become stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, had become homes again. I wondered how people lived in these spaces that used to be shops, with the lingering smells of merchandise.
**Bachelor Fads**
Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brickwork and large doors, which were used to bring in curtains from trains on the nearby railway. However, Gilbert didn't want an open-plan space because it was hard to separate work from home life. So, he used a large sheet of corrugated plastic to divide the space near the entrance. This created a hallway and directed attention to the kitchen in the middle of the flat. He wanted the kitchen to be a neutral area for both cooking for friends and making coffee for clients. To balance the modern look of the plastic and steel kitchen, he used light wood for the floors. His flat is filled with futuristic furniture, but also with sentimental pieces from his parents or bought from markets.
**Bruce Chatwin**
Bruce Chatwin's life was full of secrets and mysteries, making his nomadic lifestyle a topic of interest. Despite this, he was a brilliant and unique writer. His first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, changed travel writing. It combined the excitement of a thriller, the charm of romantic fiction, and deep insights. Chatwin often mixed fact with fiction, changing details to make stories more interesting. His book suggested that through travel, one could discover entire histories that seemed to exist just to captivate future explorers.
**Swimming**
During a heavy summer rain in 1996, I ran across my lawn and took shelter in the pool. As I swam, I watched raindrops create small fountains and bubbles on the water's surface. The best moments were when the storm got stronger, silencing the birds, and a mist rose from the pool as if it was reaching for the sky. It was then that I thought of swimming across Britain, following the rain to the sea. I wanted to escape the routine of swimming laps and explore the wild, unmarked parts of the world. In a world where everything is labeled and explained, activities like walking, cycling, and swimming help us reconnect with nature. A swimming journey would let me explore the mysterious parts of our world, like dark woods or high mountains, that still hold secrets.

'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that humans cry for no clear evolutionary reason. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying has social importance. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps form a bond between mother and child. Many think tears in children show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than the visual signal it gives. In early human groups, crying might have helped build trust and social connections. Tears can also have other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for people facing injustice. Sometimes, we cry without wanting to, like when we hear beautiful music or moving speeches. We might cry during a sentimental movie, especially when with others rather than alone. Crying clearly has a social role, but research is still ongoing.'

**The Heat is On**
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it affect us? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but its exact consequences are unclear. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on Earth, changes in climate will impact plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans rely on these natural resources to produce food, build cities, and support billions of people. Any changes to these resources are important.
The challenge is understanding how the world will change and what causes these changes. Over the last 100 years, human activities have increased the levels of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperatures. These gases are likely affecting the climate, but our limited understanding of the global heat balance makes the future uncertain. We do know that greenhouse gas levels and global temperatures have changed together over the past 40,000 years, suggesting a strong connection.
Research shows that Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C over the past century. Most scientists believe this warming is not natural and is partly due to human pollution. To predict future conditions, scientists use computer models called general circulation models (GCMs). These models use physics and chemistry to analyze climate factors like temperature and solar radiation. However, they are simplified versions of reality and have limitations. Despite these challenges, most agree that climate change will happen faster than before.
GCMs predict that by 2100, the average global temperature could rise by 1°C to 3.5°C, sea levels could rise by 15-95 cm, and precipitation patterns could change. Extreme weather events like heatwaves, floods, and droughts may become more common. These changes could impact ecosystems, such as forests and grasslands, and the resources we depend on, like food and water. Some effects might be irreversible and harmful, but not all changes will be negative. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat yields by reducing frost damage.
However, many predicted effects of climate warming are not beneficial. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry regions or areas with existing shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is already experiencing less rainfall and changes in seasonal patterns. Glacial processes may also change, affecting ice and wildlife habitats. The Arctic ice cover might melt completely, which could help marine transport but increase iceberg risks.
The most noticeable effect of global warming could be rising sea levels, caused by warmer water expanding and melting ice. With about half of the world's population living in coastal areas, rising sea levels could lead to severe consequences, like flooding in cities such as London, New York, and Tokyo. Many people could lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island nations are at risk of disappearing entirely if worst-case scenarios occur, which would be devastating for their people and cultures.

'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day round trip to Mars. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This will be the profile of the first astronauts to go to Mars if multi-millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to launch a capsule on 5 January 2018 are successful. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, as saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth are in the right position for a launch is in 2031. It's a big challenge, but the race is on to create systems with completely new technologies. If these can be developed quickly enough, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it never leaves Earth, the efforts to reach these ambitious goals will still be valuable, as they will help future missions.'

AESTHETICS
Sometimes, the very existence of art can make it hard to understand aesthetic theory. This is because art is often seen as just physical objects like buildings, books, paintings, or statues, separate from human experience. However, the true essence of art is what it does to our experiences. This misunderstanding can make it difficult to truly appreciate art.
Moreover, when art becomes famous and admired over time, it can create fixed ideas that block new insights. Once an art piece is considered a classic, it often gets disconnected from the human experiences and conditions that created it. This separation makes it hard to understand the deeper meaning of art, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often placed in a separate category, away from other human activities and achievements.
The main challenge for someone writing about the philosophy of art is to connect art back to everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art should be seen as part of human experience. To understand art, we need to look at the ordinary experiences that we don't usually consider as art. This means taking a different approach to understanding art.
For example, you can enjoy flowers without knowing about plant biology. But to understand how flowers grow, you need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. Similarly, to understand art, we should start with everyday experiences that capture our attention and bring us joy.
Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comic strips without thinking of them as art. This is because traditional art is often seen as something that belongs in museums and galleries. However, people naturally seek enjoyable experiences in their daily lives. Even those who criticize the idea of art being only in museums often still separate art from everyday life.
The best times for appreciating art are when it is closely connected to everyday activities. This is when people truly enjoy and value art the most.

**Observing Lions**
People often imagine lions hunting as a perfect team. In the evening light, a group of lions quietly moves and surrounds their prey, like skilled hunters. Lions seem to be very social animals, working together for a common goal, which is to catch their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. When we began our research in 1978, we wanted to understand why lions hunt together, raise their cubs, and scare away rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its offspring survive, then working together might not always be beneficial. If an animal is too generous, others might benefit at its cost. So, why do lions cooperate? We thought we could find the answer in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. Like the noble gases krypton, argon, and neon, lions are inactive. It has taken many research methods to learn about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand the answers to our questions.
**Pop Music Review**
The release of Bedrock's third album was a big moment for the band. "New Life" started a new trend in rock music in the country for the rest of the decade. The old style of serious and plain rock music was replaced by a lighter, more melodic style. The album mixed social observations with strong emotions, along with sounds of fairground organs and brass bands. Humor and irony were important, and the singers didn't hide their accents. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting and observing different styles and were clever songwriters. They sang about traditional English topics like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its deep, gentle sadness in songs like "So Low," a beautiful tune about weather, and "To the Brink," a serious ballad. The beauty of "New Life" is its high quality - 16 tracks with no filler, which is rare in the era of long CDs.
**Extract from an Autobiography**
As a child, I was fascinated by stories of "The Sibyl," wise women who had great influence in ancient times. I first heard about them in a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered nine books to Tarquin, King of Rome, for 300 gold pieces. He refused, so she burned three books and offered the remaining six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He finally bought the last three for the full price. I understood that there was a deep truth in the story - a lesson in sales and life. I was sometimes a lonely only child. I would ask to play with other children and be refused. My mother told me to do something so interesting that other kids would want to join me. It worked, and it was a lesson I never forgot. When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something I wanted to learn about, something relevant to my life. I'm not a big traveler, so I sent my editor a long list of places I didn't want to visit. I'm only interested in ruins because I like to travel in my mind through time.
**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**
When you submit your manuscript, it usually ends up in a pile waiting to be sorted. This pile is called the "slush pile." The person sorting it is often a junior editor or an experienced freelancer who works part-time. They don't have much influence, but they want to find something original. The junior editor wants to make a name for themselves and find an author, while the freelancer wants to keep their job. If they think your novel is good, they will pass it to a senior editor, and it might be discussed at an acquisition meeting. The editor will need to justify accepting your novel based on its quality and potential sales. They will also consider if you, as an author, seem like a long-term prospect, which you will have assured them of in your letter. Another important factor is how promotable you are, as a new novel needs all the help it can get. Publishers often like to meet a potential author before making an offer.

**Advertising on Trial**
If you worked in an advertising agency in the early 1990s, it might have been a very challenging time for you. The economy was in a recession, which was worse than expected. In Britain, for example, the GDP went down in 1991, interest rates were very high, people spent less money, many lost their jobs, and many homes were taken back by banks. Every business was affected, especially the car and construction industries, which saw a 30% drop.
Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help the company make money, and their work was closely watched by their bosses. They also had to do more with less money, as budgets were cut.
Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing was growing. Companies started to focus more on making products that customers wanted, rather than just what was easy for them to produce. This shift meant that marketing activities received more attention from management, and some brands started to be marketed more effectively. This increased the status of marketing professionals but also added to their responsibilities.
Marketing was often seen as a solution to all problems, and since about half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising, the pressure was on advertising professionals. The 1980s were a good time for advertising, but the early 1990s were tough. The recession made companies look closely at their advertising spending, and many questioned if it was worth the cost. They wanted to know exactly what they were getting for their money.
As a result, advertising was under scrutiny. Companies wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, and media placement. They wanted the best people working hard to produce great work. This meant that advertising professionals had to find ways to do more with less, just like their clients.
Several factors made creating effective advertising difficult. Some were due to the recession, like debates over production costs and a reluctance to take risks. Other challenges were unrelated to the economy, such as demographic changes, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, more sponsorships, stricter advertising laws, and the challenge of advertising in other countries.
These issues forced advertising professionals to reconsider the saying: "Only half my advertising works. The trouble is I don't know which half." There was more pressure than ever to make sure advertising was effective.
Unfortunately, help for improving advertising was not easy to find. Companies and agencies were too busy dealing with these challenges to share their strategies. Those who were successful often kept their methods secret. Conferences and seminars offered some help, but books on advertising were not very useful. They often treated advertising with too much respect, suggesting that all advertising work was of high quality and good value, which was not always true.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**
When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was an unusual choice among my peers. Cooking wasn't a popular career choice. On the surface, being a chef seems unattractive. Chefs work long hours, under pressure, doing basic tasks, and the pay is low. But these things didn't discourage me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were tough, and the social life felt closed and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect escape from this. It offered a seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life. My desire to cook wasn't just a reaction to being a student. It also represented an artistic ideal for me. I first saw this ideal when I ate at a famous London restaurant. It was eye-opening. I still remember my starter clearly. After that meal, I wanted to thank the chef deeply. I felt happy and light for days. After this experience, I wanted to learn the secrets of this amazing art. I turned my student life into a preparation for entering the culinary world. My history degree felt empty, distracting me from my real passion. I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets and delicatessens, and making elaborate meals.
**The Swimming Instructor**
The school's swimming instructor was a former drill sergeant, small and muscular, with tattooed arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this move until the lesson ended. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. The instructor was strict, and every time I came up from the water, he criticized me: 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes!' The following week, I went up to the high diving board. It was fixed, and its front edge bent slightly downward. It seemed very high as I stood there, trying to gather my courage. Gradually, the echoing voices faded, and I felt like I was in silence. I moved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up, not down, and jumped. For a brief moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I fell awkwardly, and my legs were everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disapproval and shook his head. But even he couldn't take away my happiness. That's what they mean by 'free as a bird,' I thought.
**The Traveller**
For those of us who value a comfortable bed, running water, and the likelihood of living at least until tomorrow, the idea of a traveller is both confusing and fascinating. These are people who are drawn to the unknown, who choose to risk their lives by climbing dangerous, icy mountains; who sail alone in small boats through huge waves; who will eat insects if there's nothing better, and who can live for months in the uncertainty of the unknown. It's easy to see these people as odd - and they are - similar to hermits, freefall divers, or writers. They exist, but their strange, uncomfortable world is far from our everyday experience and can be dismissed as irrelevant. We can ignore them and return to our world of microwaves and answering machines, happy that the only risks we face are predictable ones, like crossing a busy street.
**Sailing**
Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He doesn't claim to be a top sailor, but he is clearly competent. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he likes to write about his sailing experiences. Sailing provides plenty of challenges and successes for him to write about. Raban's small boat has an electronic device that tells sailors their exact position anywhere on Earth. While he likes this tool, Raban has a somewhat old-fashioned view of other sailing aids. He believes the invention of the compass was a mistake, causing a 'break in the relationship between man and sea.' Raban argues that since the compass was invented, about a thousand years ago, sailors focus on it instead of studying the waves and feeling the sea. The ocean, once full of activity, is now just a space. Since the helmsman's job is just to keep a steady course, he can be replaced by an autopilot for long periods. This might be why Raban had time to observe the waves so closely.

**Holiday Reading**
Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are closely linked. Books help us feel more connected to the world. We can relate our experiences to those in books from long ago or faraway places because there are fewer types of people than there are people. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought were unique to us, or express our thoughts with clarity we can't achieve. What is unclear in us is clearly expressed in their words, especially if the book is from a different place or time. We feel thankful to these authors for helping us understand ourselves. Through reading and travel, we break free from routine. Our eyes are most open in a new place, or when reading a great book, which shows us things we ignored before. Our mind becomes aware of new details, like the sky's colors, a friend's hypocrisy, or a hidden sadness we didn't know we had.
**Author's Note**
These travel reflections were published in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have restored some small cuts made by the editor, but added little else. I corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were important details. I could have made more changes, but that would never end. For example, in an article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell a year later. If I changed the article to predict this, it would not be a true report from that time. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, unaware of the future, trying to understand what had already happened. This is the story of mass travel: the world opening up to people with no special skills, just a ticket. But I believe my fellow travelers are not blind. Even a postcard can have a purpose.
**Ecotourism**
If there were awards for overused tourism phrases, "ecotourism" would win. The term appeared in the early 1980s, as people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized travelers wanted to believe their trips wouldn't harm the environment. It quickly became a popular marketing term. Now, "ecotourism" includes anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a one-hour boat trip in Australia. Any tour involving culture, nature, wildlife, or adventure is labeled ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but without clear rules, many travelers are confused by the term.
**Transylvanian Journey**
I lost my notebook from my Transylvanian journey for 50 years, but found it by luck. It helped me remember that time, but not perfectly. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than expected, staying in welcoming homes for weeks. When I stopped moving, I stopped writing, thinking there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again, and sometimes only took notes instead of writing full stories. Worried that details might be out of order, I added warnings in my book. But then I realized this book is not a guidebook, so I let the story flow without too many warnings.

**Fashion**
Fashion is often thought of as a modern idea, linked to the growth of capitalism in the 1800s and 1900s. However, many fashion historians argue that fashion, in terms of style and design, has a long history. They often start with the rise of markets and trade in the 1500s and 1600s. As societies have become more complex, populations have grown, and new ways to make different types of clothing and accessories have been discovered, the meanings of clothing have also become more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing or accessory means. For example, a man's suit, which seems very standard, can have different meanings in different situations and to different people.
**Writer**
Stories about publishers fighting over new manuscripts have given a false idea of what life is like for most novelists. For those of us not at the top of the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smartest among us write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs that are secure even if the book doesn't become a hit. Others, like me, do various literary jobs, such as teaching, running workshops, and writing articles like this one. I've heard about writing jobs at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten one. Somehow, by balancing part-time jobs, using credit cards, and often with help from the people mentioned in Acknowledgements, the novel gets written.
**Sudden Fame**
The small venues we were playing at across the country started to sell out, and extra security was needed to control the growing number of screaming fans. We had to use secret entrances to the places we performed to avoid being mobbed. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being chased by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, this was replaced by a strange confidence that only naturally shy people in similar situations can understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Future Challenges**
Technology keeps changing how we live, work, and enjoy our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, we had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, live music performances and full-time jobs for musicians have decreased. It's clear that more people will keep accessing music because it meets many human needs. Music is part of every big national event and offers many activities for individuals. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn musical instruments.
I believe people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry is a big part of Britain's economy, and musical skills will remain important for many jobs, especially in media. Besides job opportunities, playing an instrument can help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that listening to or making music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. Although these results need more proof, studies in Europe show that group music lessons can improve social skills and concentration in children, including those with behavior issues. Further research is looking into how playing an instrument might help develop skills that can be used in other areas, like good study habits and organization.
In the short term, there will still be a demand for music lessons. But what about the long term? Will things change, and how? I think two things might happen. First, people will listen to more types of music, with new genres mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more in composing and performing music, making it easier for people to create music without needing as much technical skill. This might reduce the need for live performances and musicians focused only on performing. At the same time, more people of all ages might want to make music themselves, often in community settings that reflect local musical traditions.
To prepare for this future, the music profession needs to change. Music lessons should help more people learn different instruments throughout their lives. This will change the music curriculum and how progress is measured, making it relevant to more people. Musicians will need to be trained to inspire and teach people of all ages, work with large and diverse groups, and have skills in communication, social interaction, entrepreneurship, and management for community work. This is a big change from traditional methods and will require accountability to the public. Positively, this is a chance for music educators to show the quality of music teaching available.
Finally, we need to raise the importance of music in our lives. Music is crucial but often overlooked. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**
Actors sometimes face criticism and disrespect. This often happens when they talk about their work in interviews, which can lead to clichés or gossip. They could learn from dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it," when asked about her dancing. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, once wrote that acting only has life when performed. Discussing it makes it seem empty and theoretical. Acting has no strict rules, except maybe being heard clearly. With each new play, actors start fresh, learning and growing with the characters and the writer's insights. After a play ends, actors feel empty until the next project. This emptiness is noticeable when discussing theatre work.
**A Review of Hamlet**
Adrian Lester's performance as Hamlet is a mix of youth and maturity, showing simplicity and confidence. His control over the text and his actions make him a standout actor. Lester plays a tense young man with hidden anger, using sharp wit and humor that make him both intimidating and likable. His performance is skillful, even if understated. Watch how his body seems ready to come alive. Similarly, Handy's portrayal of Horatio shows a body moved by an inner force. This raises questions about acting and behavior: Is acting just copying real life, or is it something more? What drives these performances, both morally and physically? This is a key question in theatre.
**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**
This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager projects the script on a screen. Actors listen quietly to others, noticing the effect of the words. When it's their turn, they read a line, think about its meaning, and wait for the impulse to speak. For example, with the line "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, let the thought sink in, and visualize a scene. This helps them find the reason to speak, which the director calls "The pathway to the line." Impulses can come from outside or inside. Actors should look into each other's eyes and consider their character's situation. The director encourages actors to approach this with an open mind, trusting that something will happen.
**The Perfect Theatre**
The perfect theatre should make you feel like your presence matters. Going to a live performance is an event, and the staff should recognize this. It's discouraging if the staff treats it like just another job. The theatre should create a connection between the performer and the audience. Everyone should feel they have a fair view of the actor, not too far away, and able to hear and see clearly. The size of the auditorium is important; it should fit the human voice and body. If the space is too big, it loses the human element central to drama. Many theatres from the late 1800s got this right, creating spaces that embrace the stage. Theatres with a sense of history, like worn steps in a church, give a feeling of past human presence. You can't please everyone with a play, and audiences don't always know what they want to see. When you go to the theatre, you want to experience something unexpected, something you couldn't imagine at home.

**Paul Simon**
In the 1950s, rock and roll was mainly popular among young people, but it also had a big impact on middle-class and older people. It set the stage for future rock stars who were inspired by this new and exciting music. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this music was through Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. This show was a must-listen for many future rock stars. Like John Lennon in Liverpool, who listened to Radio Luxembourg, Paul Simon was captivated by the music on Freed's show. He was ready to move from just listening to music to creating his own.
**Snow**
There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong, pushing me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow beneath me collapsed. I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, leaving only a thin layer that I broke through. I pulled myself out, feeling shaken and worried about what could have happened if the hole had been deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In an hour, I had only traveled about half a mile. It was clear I needed to change my plan.
**Qualitative Research**
There are many books now that try to help researchers with qualitative research. While they talk a lot about collecting data, they often don't explain how to analyze it. Many researchers find data analysis mysterious. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to share how they analyze their data. The goal was to provide insight into the process of data analysis, not to create a guidebook. This means making hidden methods more clear. Although this seems easy, it is actually quite difficult. We allowed our contributors to present their work in different styles, including personal stories and more formal approaches.

**Screen Learning**
A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show he watched recently. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't remember much. Many people are eager to use the internet and computers for learning, but is learning from a screen really effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but the son was more interested in playing with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that gives impressions and suggestions. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is dialogue with teachers or parents. It needs to be guided. Using new technology to teach children is fine, but formal education is still very important.
**Hollywood**
By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. The local people didn't like it at first, seeing their area of Los Angeles changed by these newcomers. But eventually, they accepted it because of the success it brought. In Hollywood, success is measured by how much money a film makes. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: it might make someone a star, but it will definitely make money. In less than a century, Hollywood grew from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot: a hundred years ago, you would walk through orange groves to get to the village store. Yet, in some ways, it is still like a village, with a narrow focus - just a part of Los Angeles. For those who live and work there, the main topic of conversation is films: how much they have made, who is dating whom, who has been betrayed, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to leave: they work there but live elsewhere. Still, it is the place where almost everyone in show business eventually goes.
**Photography**
Photography was created by nineteenth-century artists as a new form of art. These artists wanted a lasting and accurate record of what they saw around them, and they found it. The combination of light, lens, shutter, and a surface with light-sensitive chemicals created images that were more lasting, realistic, and detailed than what painters could make in weeks or months. This caused some concern among other artists, and after their initial excitement, art critics argued that photography was not true art. They said that because photography relied on mechanical means, it couldn't be considered a product of human creativity. Despite the critics, photographers knew they had discovered a new art form and a new way to express themselves. They used their tools like other artists used brushes and pencils - to interpret the world and show their vision of nature and the people in it.
**Book Illustration**
During the time when book illustrations were in black and white, it was common for every children's book to have some form of illustration. This also applied to many novels for older readers, although this became less common as the number of printed copies decreased. Children's publishing was still very active, but it was mostly done on a low budget, which led to a lot of routine and average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The black-and-white archive is a mix of ordinary and valuable work, a great place for research or browsing, where you can find treasures or start to appreciate this artistic period again. The real treasures are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reissues of individual titles, new publications about the artists, or exhibitions of original books and drawings. There are signs that this is starting to happen, and the familiar process of bringing back old styles is underway. Eventually, a smart publisher will see the potential for a series of classic children's book illustrations from this period, either as reprints or new editions using the original artwork.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**
Some time ago, a website warned about the dangers of public check-ins—telling everyone online where you are. The message was clear: you might think you're just saying, "Hey, I'm here," but you're also letting everyone know you're not at home, which might not be safe. This highlighted the growing concern that sharing too much online can have negative effects. The internet offers many exciting opportunities to share our lives with a global audience, promising things like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the online world, sharing confessions, photos, and stories. But soon, we realize it's a crowded and risky place, and we can feel lost.
Is this depressing? Maybe, but don't lose hope. This future has a guide, created by early internet users. In the early days of the web, these pioneers explored the internet and faced its challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the ups and downs of fame, all before social media existed. These early bloggers have already experienced what many of us are going through now. Before we forget their stories, it's worth learning from them. As the saying goes, those who don't learn from history are doomed to repeat it.
In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting online. Back then, the web was mostly used by students, scientists, and a few curious teenagers like him. The web was created at CERN, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were drawn to his bold use of this new medium. Hall's rule was simple: if you crossed his path, you might end up on his site, and no topic was off-limits. While some saw him as an exhibitionist, others recognized the art in his work.
One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video called "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the problem remains. Sharing online is great, but if you expect it to make people like you, you'll be disappointed.
In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including some she had criticized, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect": the feeling that we can say things online that we wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to big mistakes.
Armstrong's story ended well. Though she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and restarted her blog, focusing on her family. Now, she's a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. Once an example of online mistakes, she has become skilled at sharing her life carefully. Armstrong learned an important lesson: just because the web lets us say anything, doesn't mean we should.

'Enough Sleep? Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and wealthy countries, more people are having trouble sleeping and feeling anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books have characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep: how it works, why we need it, and what happens when we can't sleep. A main concern is that people need more sleep. A top sleep researcher says, 'People sleep less when they're busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic.' A sleep researcher did an experiment where he let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle at about eight hours of sleep. This shows they were catching up on lost sleep. In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired. They find volunteers through student newspapers. Volunteers are picked up by taxi, paid £5 an hour, and asked to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures them: 'Some people worry because we put electrodes on their heads, but we can't see their dreams or thoughts.' The lab is more interested in physical effects. In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. Volunteers come at 2 pm, when people naturally feel sleepy, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road on the screen seems endless, the sun is bright, and the air is warm. Young men say they won't fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video of one trying not to. At first, he sits up straight, eyes open. Then he starts blinking more and nodding off. Each time, he wakes up suddenly, but the car has already gone off the road. Coffee might help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for over half an hour, even with no sleep. She suggests using tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum, especially for shift workers. But what do we really know about sleep? Humans, like other mammals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, we go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams usually happen in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Beyond this, we have theories. Some say sleep repairs the body, restores muscles, or rests the brain's speech and creativity areas. But these might also happen when we're awake and relaxed, so no one is sure. Scientists are quite sure that women sleep half an hour longer than men and that older people need less sleep, but they don't know why. When asked why we sleep, some researchers say, 'Sleep helps us pass time safely.' In the past, people may have slept differently. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people had different sleep patterns. They went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then had a 'morning sleep.' This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poorest people benefited most from this quiet time. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made most people work longer hours in lit buildings, changing sleep patterns for everyone except some country people. Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western places, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, then get up again. The idea of sleeping all night doesn't apply. In some tribal societies, noise, fire watching, and predators make continuous sleep impossible. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.'

'We are talking about big boots here. Really big boots. I stood in my expensive cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. Money was no problem. I wore a full cowboy outfit, but I wasn't a cowboy. It didn't feel right. I looked at the Arizona mountains and realized I didn't belong there. I flew in from Denver early in the morning, thinking I might look like a cowboy. But that feeling disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He wore a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and carried a dirty bag. He noticed my new boots, raised an eyebrow, and left without a word. 
I wished there was an outfit for an ex-racing driver that made me feel like I fit in. Something that made me feel like I belonged, no matter where I was. I loved being a racing driver. I was addicted to it, and it was all I knew. But I don't race anymore. Even if I wanted to, I couldn't. So, what do I do now? A racing driver should have other plans for when they stop racing. I thought I did, but they disappeared when I needed them. 
How about being a commentator at the racetrack? 'We have fifteen former drivers ahead of you, Forrest. We'll call you.' Or maybe selling classic cars? That idea lasted a while, but nobody was buying old Ferraris, and Honda was changing its dealers. So, I left before it was too late. Being an 'ex' anything is tough. Who wants to hear about how I almost became World Champion? Nobody likes stories that end in 'almost'. Even if I had been champion, people would only listen for a few minutes. Last year's champion is old news. 
I don't want sympathy, and I don't get any. Why should I? I had a good career, made money, and saved some. But I miss racing. I miss the thrill of driving a powerful car. I miss the danger and the excitement. I miss the people and the reporters who cared about what I said. Being a little famous wasn't so bad. Businessmen and politicians liked to say they knew me. Kids wanted my autograph. But now that I don't race... Last week, the phone rang only twice. I have a lot of free time. 
I looked at the blue sky. No buzzards. Maybe Arizona doesn't have them. But some small birds in a cactus were singing. I never thought the desert had songbirds. I realized that a fake cowboy in designer boots has a lot to learn.'

**Vancouver**
In the past ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evenings, people like to walk around the city, and if you join them, you will probably hear many different languages. People choose Vancouver because of its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and opportunities for education and jobs. Some people complain about the fast construction of new buildings, but it's clear that new residents and tourism have helped the city grow. Vancouver used to be called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Even though the name is not used as much now, Vancouver is still a major gateway.
**Putting Pen to Paper**
Journalists, like me, are often not good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because we focus so much on making an impact in our work that we lose the natural flow of a letter. Real artists, who don't always think about the effect of their words (even if they rewrite a lot), don't have this problem. I think a true artist knows how their words will affect people. For example, when Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about how the mix of long words made them powerful, but it showed he was a great writer.
**Supermarket Opening**
In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal would often come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that celebrities are not needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can do it for free? Last week, people waiting for the new Superbuy store to open didn't care who cut the ribbon, as long as they were first in line. One customer heard that the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel proud and those who came later feel jealous.

**Citizen Kane**
When the film *Citizen Kane* was finally released in 1941, there was a lot of excitement and controversy. The release was delayed because the distributors were worried about what William Randolph Hearst, who the film was supposedly about, might do to them. Despite getting great reviews, the film was not a commercial hit at first. It was television that later made it popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most influential film, inspiring many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said its success came from not knowing what he could or couldn't do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper owner who was similar to Hearst, Welles knew he had found the perfect project for himself as both director and actor, and he took the opportunity with great enthusiasm.
**Dermot and Carmel**
Dermot noticed that Carmel seemed a bit strange that morning. He mentioned twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to chat with someone, and that was the best place to do it. Carmel nodded her head in agreement but seemed like she wasn't really listening. Dermot asked, "Will you be all right? What are you going to do today?" Carmel smiled and said, "Funny you should ask that. I was just thinking I had nothing to do all day, so I was going to walk downtown and look at the shops. It feels almost wrong to just spend the day doing nothing." Dermot smiled back and said, "You're allowed to enjoy yourself. And as I said, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't go to any trouble." Carmel replied, "No, that's fine."
**Title Race**
Human nature can be quite amusing. A recent study showed that job titles are a major cause of jealousy and tension at work. A survey by a top recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey revealed that 70% of office workers would prefer a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title over a pay raise. If our desire for impressive titles is so strong that it even beats our basic desire for more money, we are in a difficult situation. In today's world, nobody wants to be seen as less important. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to describe the same roles.

I was in Vienna to take photos. That was usually why I traveled anywhere. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light could change a scene and how one photo could capture the essence of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo, and as long as I had film, there was a chance. I had a routine: finish one roll, load another, and keep looking for the right moment. This had been my way for a long time.
Once, I took a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well that became very popular. Newspapers and magazines around the world wanted it. It was a brief moment of success, mostly due to luck. After that, I decided to work freelance, which seemed smart at the time. But life didn't go as planned, and the mid-nineties weren't as successful as I had hoped. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which wasn't bad.
The Vienna job came by chance. I had taken photos in London for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job, and they asked me to take over. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was happy to go because things at home weren't great. A week in snowy Vienna sounded good to me.
They put me up at the Europa Hotel in the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife during the summer, but it was busy and not very memorable. This time, in cold January, it felt different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos. The first day, I didn't take any pictures. I rode the trams around the city, getting a feel for the place. The weather was cold and set, like the old baroque buildings. I hadn't seen Schussner's work from other seasons because I wanted this to be my Vienna.
A photograph captures a moment, but you have to wait for the right moment. I spent time looking around until I was ready. The next morning, I went out at dawn. Snow had fallen overnight, making Stephansplatz look untouched and empty. I wasn't sure how to capture the cathedral in one shot because its spire was tall and the base was large. I decided to focus on part of it, hoping to capture something magical. Photography has always had a magical quality, even when you understand how it works. Watching a photo develop is still mysterious, and that feeling stays with you. That's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't really surprise me.

Kinetic Art Rejoice -- Something amazing has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place full of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, heavily advertised show, but rather a unique exploration of a nearly forgotten art form from the last 60 years. A new exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the twentieth century. It shows that creating art that moves by itself or explores the idea of movement has been an ongoing, though often unnoticed, theme in some of the most interesting creative work of this century.
